title: `impl` type aliases depending on lifetimes introduced by function pointers cause an ICE

labels.name: I-ICE
labels.description: Issue: The compiler panicked, giving an Internal Compilation Error (ICE) ❄️

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
I found an ICE while attempting to use an `impl` type alias in a function pointer type while playing around with [`type_alias_impl_trait`](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/63063).

```rust
#![feature(type_alias_impl_trait)]

type Iter<'a> = impl Iterator<Item = u32> + 'a;

fn whee() -> for<'a> fn(&'a [u32]) -> Iter<'a> {
    |a| a.iter().copied()
}
``` 

Here's the [playground link](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=9d20d885c7cd26397fdc9d061e627de7) to the snippet above, which was running `rustc 1.70.0-nightly (0c61c7a97 2023-03-25) running on x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu` at the time of the panic.

The head of the panic is as follows:
```
error: internal compiler error: compiler/rustc_hir_typeck/src/inherited.rs:105:13: escaping bound vars in predicate Obligation(predicate=Binder(TraitPredicate(<Iter<'a> as std::marker::Sized>, polarity:Positive), []), depth=0)
 --> src/lib.rs:5:14
  |
5 | fn whee() -> for<'a> fn(&'a [u32]) -> Iter<'a> {
  |              ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

thread 'rustc' panicked at 'Box<dyn Any>', /rustc/0c61c7a978fe9f7b77a1d667c77d2202dadd1c10/compiler/rustc_errors/src/lib.rs:995:33
stack backtrace:
    ...
```

```
note: we would appreciate a bug report: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/new?labels=C-bug%2C+I-ICE%2C+T-compiler&template=ice.md

note: rustc 1.70.0-nightly (0c61c7a97 2023-03-25) running on x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu

note: compiler flags: --crate-type lib -C embed-bitcode=no -C codegen-units=1 -C debuginfo=2

note: some of the compiler flags provided by cargo are hidden

query stack during panic:
#0 [typeck] type-checking `whee`
#1 [type_of] computing type of `Iter::{opaque#0}`
#2 [check_mod_item_types] checking item types in top-level module
#3 [analysis] running analysis passes on this crate
end of query stack
```
</details>

The error is also reproducible with HRTBs.

```rust
#![feature(type_alias_impl_trait)]

type Iter<'a> = impl Iterator<Item = u32> + 'a;

fn whee() -> Box<dyn for<'a> FnOnce(&'a [u32]) -> Iter<'a>> {
    |a| a.iter().copied()
}
```

Here's the [playground link](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=49e3a0e335a8ac0a5a6b09be807f467c) to the above snippet, which was running `note: rustc 1.70.0-nightly (0c61c7a97 2023-03-25) running on x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu` at the time of the panic.

The head of the panic is identical to the head of the first panic.

```
note: we would appreciate a bug report: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/new?labels=C-bug%2C+I-ICE%2C+T-compiler&template=ice.md

note: rustc 1.70.0-nightly (0c61c7a97 2023-03-25) running on x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu

note: compiler flags: --crate-type lib -C embed-bitcode=no -C codegen-units=1 -C debuginfo=2

note: some of the compiler flags provided by cargo are hidden

query stack during panic:
#0 [typeck] type-checking `whee`
#1 [type_of] computing type of `Iter::{opaque#0}`
#2 [check_mod_item_types] checking item types in top-level module
#3 [analysis] running analysis passes on this crate
end of query stack
```
</details>

If, however, the lifetime provided to the type alias is not higher-ranked (is this appropriate terminology??), but rather originates from the function itself, the compiler does not panic.

```rust
#![feature(type_alias_impl_trait)]

type Iter<'a> = impl Iterator<Item = u32> + 'a;

fn whee<'a>() -> for<'b> fn(&'b [u32]) -> Iter<'a> {
    |_a| [1, 2, 3].into_iter()
}
```

Here's the [playground link](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=e1dd6dc0f5b4bb716082385bf973d87d) to the above snippet, which was *presumably also* running `rustc 1.70.0-nightly (0c61c7a97 2023-03-25) running on x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu` at the time of the panicn't.
